title: How to Connect Ceiling Fan Wires

steps.title: Turn off the power from the circuit or breaker box.
steps.content: Turn off the power from the circuit or breaker box . Read the inside of your breaker or circuit box and locate the switch that controls the power to your fan. Once you find the right switch, flip it to the off position. It’s important that the power running to the wires in your ceiling is off or you could electrocute yourself. [1] X Research source There is usually a schematic or table on the inside of your circuit breaker panel that will tell you what part of the house each circuit controls. If you don't know which switch controls your fan, turn on all the lights in your house. Once the lights are on, flip each switch until you switch off the power in the part of the house where the fan is located. That switch most likely controls the power to your fan.

steps.title: Read the instruction manual that came with your fan.
steps.content: Read the instruction manual that came with your fan. Some fan models have special warnings or instructions that you need to read before you start installing it. Read the entire manual to make sure you're installing it correctly. For instance, fans that have lights will require a slightly different installation process than fans without them.

steps.title: Identify the individual wires coming out of your ceiling.
steps.content: Identify the individual wires coming out of your ceiling. There should be a white, copper or green, and black wire coming out of the ceiling's electrical box. Some setups will also have a blue wire, which powers the lights on your fan. [2] X Expert Source James Hornof Master Electrician Expert Interview. 7 September 2021. The white wire is your neutral wire, the copper wire is the grounded wire, and the black wire powers the fan. [3] X Expert Source James Hornof Master Electrician Expert Interview. 7 September 2021. [4] X Research source The black and blue wires are called hot wires because they hold electrical current. If you have a blue and black wire hanging out from your ceiling, you should also have 2 switches on your wall.

steps.title: Examine the wires coming out of your fan.
steps.content: Examine the wires coming out of your fan. Your fan should have a green, white, and black wire coming out of the top of it. If your fan also has a light, it will have a blue wire. There should also be a green grounding wire attached to the fan bracket itself. [5] X Expert Source James Hornof Master Electrician Expert Interview. 7 September 2021. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Screw the ceiling fan bracket into the ceiling.
steps.content: Screw the ceiling fan bracket into the ceiling. Thread the wires coming out of your ceiling through the center of the bracket so that they hang freely below it. Line up your ceiling fan bracket with the holes in the electrical box that’s in your ceiling. Place the screws that came with the bracket into the holes and turn them clockwise with a screwdriver to tighten them. This should attach and secure the fan bracket to your ceiling. [7] X Research source Make sure that you tighten the screws well or the fan will wobble when you turn it on.

steps.title: Hang the ceiling fan in the bracket.
steps.content: Hang the ceiling fan in the bracket. Slide the top of the ceiling fan into the groove in the bracket and hang it. Fans will have different setups and brackets, but all modern fans will allow you to hang the fan on the bracket so that you can connect the wires. [8] X Research source If you can't hang your fan, have someone hold it in place for you as you install it.

steps.title: Strip the ends
steps.content: Strip the ends of the wires. To connect your wires, the copper ends must be exposed. Remove the plastic caps that are on the ends of your wires. Use a stepladder to reach the wires in your ceiling and carefully cut away the plastic coating about 2 inches (5.1 cm) from the end of the wires with a wire cutter. Snip the plastic and slide it off to expose the copper wires. Repeat the process on the wires coming out of your fan. [9] X Research source If the copper ends of your wires are already exposed, you can skip this step.

steps.title: Twist both white wires together.
steps.content: Twist both white wires together. The white wires are your neutral wires. Connect the white wire coming out of your ceiling to the white wire coming out of the top of the fan. Twist the copper ends together until they are securely connected to each other. [10] X Research source Connecting the neutral wires will complete the circuit in your fan. You may want to wear thick gloves to prevent yourself from getting cut on the copper.

steps.title: Connect the 2 green wires together.
steps.content: Connect the 2 green wires together. Typically, a green wire is attached to your fan bracket and the other green wire is attached to the fan itself. Twist the copper ends of the wires together to connect them together. Leave the green or copper wire that's coming out the ceiling unattached for now. The 2 green wires are your grounded wires and prevent damage to your fan from power surges. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Connect the black and blue wires in your fan if you only have 1 switch.
steps.content: Connect the black and blue wires in your fan if you only have 1 switch. Connect the black and blue wires coming out of your fan. This will allow you to control your fan and lights with a single switch. Twist the copper ends of the black and blue wires together like you did with the previous wires. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Connect the grounded copper wire with the green wires.
steps.content: Connect the grounded copper wire with the green wires. Take the 2 green wires that you twisted together and connect them to the copper or green wire coming out of your ceiling. This will ground your fan’s internal components. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Twist your hot wires to the black wire in the ceiling.
steps.content: Twist your hot wires to the black wire in the ceiling. You should always connect your hot wires last. If you only have 1 switch, connect the bound blue and black wires to the black wire coming out of your ceiling. If you have a 2 switch setup, connect the blue and black wires to the blue and black wires coming out of your ceiling. [14] X Research source If your fan doesn't have lights, you'll only have to connect the black wires.

steps.title: Fit the plastic caps back onto the ends of the wires.
steps.content: Fit the plastic caps back onto the ends of the wires. If your wires had plastic caps on the end of the wires, replace them. Fit the caps over the twisted wires and rotate them until they are secure. If the wires didn't have plastic caps, cover the exposed ends with electrical tape so that your wires don't touch one another.

steps.title: Tuck the connected wires into the ceiling bracket.
steps.content: Tuck the connected wires into the ceiling bracket. Take your wires and tuck them into the ceiling bracket so that you can screw the faceplate into your ceiling. Make sure that none of the wires become disconnected as you do this. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Screw in the fan faceplate over the bracket.
steps.content: Screw in the fan faceplate over the bracket. Fit the fan’s faceplate over the bracket and the wires and line up the holes in the side of your fan. Use a screwdriver to turn the screws clockwise to tighten them. Screw in all the screws or your fan won’t be stable.

steps.title: Turn on the power from your breaker box and test the fan.
steps.content: Turn on the power from your breaker box and test the fan. Go back to your breaker box and flip the appropriate circuit to the on position. Then, flip the switch(es) on the wall to make sure that your fan works correctly. If you notice it wobbling, turn the fan off and make sure that the screws connecting the bracket and faceplate are tight.

steps.title: Disassemble your fan and check the connections if needed.
steps.content: Disassemble your fan and check the connections if needed. If your fan doesn't turn on, there's either an electrical problem or you didn't connect your wires correctly. Turn off the power and remove the faceplate to make sure that all the wires are connected correctly.
